title: Jenson Goh | Web Directory | Singapore Institute of Technology

meta.description: Dr Jenson is currently an Associate Professor at the Singapore Institute of Technology for 50% of his time when he focuses on the design and implementation of systems thinking and system dynamics curriculum for students and leaders while fulfilling his duties as a faculty in the Engineering Cluster in applied learning and research. He is also a member of the University's sustainability group responsible for curating and driving sustainability education among students and leaders in the industry.  In the other 50% of his time, he is the Chief Executive Officer of a boutique company called Coddiwompling that focuses on supporting organisations and/or leaders to drive transformative changes, especially from a system perspective. His company offers consultancy, customized leadership development programmes, coaching/mentoring and strategic facilitation services and has to date served more than 60 happy organisation clients both in Singapore and overseas. Dr Jenson has years of consulting work across the globe in diverse industries. He is still well sought after by companies around the world for his knowledge and capabilities in leading transformational works. Dr Jenson previously held Chief Information, Learning and Sustainability Officer positions in Monde Nissin Group, a publicly listed USD1 billion multi-national company HQ in the Philippines and had driven many successful leadership learning programmes (especially in coaching/mentoring and systems thinking) and digital transformation and sustainability's strategies and projects across Philippines, Thailand, and Singapore. Before that, he was Director of Studies at Residential College 4. His responsibility involved the realization of a transformative programme to develop students into able system thinkers. He was an international award-winning teaching case writer and multiple years NUS teaching award winner. His research strives to uncover ways to help organizations/society deal with wicked problems. He had published articles in top-tier journals and conferences, books, press and practitioner’s publications. Dr Jenson also had >16 years in strategizing IT use as a Chief Enterprise Architect. He had extensive experience driving many IT initiatives to support University’s teaching, research and administration. In 2003, he was selected by Infocomm Authority of Singapore and Sun Microsystems for the prestigious 8 months Java Black Belt programme to be groomed as a leader in Singapore’s IT industry. For his innovative use of IT and service to the University, he had won >20 international and national awards which include the NUS service champion and NUS IT Director's awards. Dr Jenson had served as the Head, Manpower and Logistics (NS) in the Singapore Police Force responsible for the operational readiness of 1,600 NSmen for more than 10 years. For his dedication, he received multiple awards from the Commissioner of Police and Division Commander including the most prestigious Home Team NS man of the year award in 2018. Dr Jenson is an avid societal contributor. He is a board member of Casa Raudha (www.casaraudha.org), Executive Committee member of Tech Talent Assembly (www.ttab.org.sg), Chairman of Singapore Our Home SG75 National Youth Competition (www.sg75.sg), and the President, the Asia Pacific Coordinating Policy Council and Policy Council member of the System Dynamics Society (www.systemdynamics.org).

text_lines: This question is for testing whether or not you are a human visitor and to prevent automated spam submissions.
PhD in Information Systems, National University of Singapore, Singapore

Dr Jenson is currently an Associate Professor at the Singapore Institute of Technology for 50% of his time when he focuses on the design and implementation of systems thinking and system dynamics curriculum for students and leaders while fulfilling his duties as a faculty in the Engineering Cluster in applied learning and research. He is also a member of the University's sustainability group responsible for curating and driving sustainability education among students and leaders in the industry.

In the other 50% of his time, he is the Chief Executive Officer of a boutique company called Coddiwompling that focuses on supporting organisations and/or leaders to drive transformative changes, especially from a system perspective. His company offers consultancy, customized leadership development programmes, coaching/mentoring and strategic facilitation services and has to date served more than 60 happy organisation clients both in Singapore and overseas. Dr Jenson has years of consulting work across the globe in diverse industries. He is still well sought after by companies around the world for his knowledge and capabilities in leading transformational works.

Dr Jenson previously held Chief Information, Learning and Sustainability Officer positions in Monde Nissin Group, a publicly listed USD1 billion multi-national company HQ in the Philippines and had driven many successful leadership learning programmes (especially in coaching/mentoring and systems thinking) and digital transformation and sustainability's strategies and projects across Philippines, Thailand, and Singapore.

Before that, he was Director of Studies at Residential College 4. His responsibility involved the realization of a transformative programme to develop students into able system thinkers. He was an international award-winning teaching case writer and multiple years NUS teaching award winner. His research strives to uncover ways to help organizations/society deal with wicked problems. He had published articles in top-tier journals and conferences, books, press and practitioner’s publications.

Dr Jenson also had >16 years in strategizing IT use as a Chief Enterprise Architect. He had extensive experience driving many IT initiatives to support University’s teaching, research and administration. In 2003, he was selected by Infocomm Authority of Singapore and Sun Microsystems for the prestigious 8 months Java Black Belt programme to be groomed as a leader in Singapore’s IT industry. For his innovative use of IT and service to the University, he had won >20 international and national awards which include the NUS service champion and NUS IT Director's awards.

Dr Jenson had served as the Head, Manpower and Logistics (NS) in the Singapore Police Force responsible for the operational readiness of 1,600 NSmen for more than 10 years. For his dedication, he received multiple awards from the Commissioner of Police and Division Commander including the most prestigious Home Team NS man of the year award in 2018. Dr Jenson is an avid societal contributor. He is a board member of Casa Raudha (www.casaraudha.org), Executive Committee member of Tech Talent Assembly (www.ttab.org.sg), Chairman of Singapore Our Home SG75 National Youth Competition (www.sg75.sg), and the President, the Asia Pacific Coordinating Policy Council and Policy Council member of the System Dynamics Society (www.systemdynamics.org).

Applying systems thinking and system dynamics in addressing complex organizational (e.g., in strategy development and implementation, in complex project management), societal, and sustainability challenges.

Uncover the intertwining relationships between people, processes, and technologies, especially in the context of driving systematic and/or transformative changes within an organization or society. Some topics include IT-enabled business transformation, ICT project management, and its dynamics.

Particularly interested in the design and application of Learning through play methodology to enhance student's engagement, deepen student's thinking capabilities, and improve student's learning while having fun doing so.

Design and writing of effective teaching case study especially in the area of change management and system dynamics and in the conduct of in-depth research case study to uncover insights of the inner working of how things in organization and society works in a certain way.
Implementation of Systems Thinking in Public Policy: Taking Eco-Product Value Realization as an example

Explore the successful cases of Eco-Product Value Realization and develop systems thinking and system dynamics models to explain the principal programs and policies leading to the successful outcomes of the Eco-Product Value Realization success stories.
Conduct the field studies of Eco-Product Value Realization in China.

Make the system dynamics modelling more accessible through group model building, help decision-makers optimize their policy-making and create real change to the world. This can be done by publishing the results in a public policy relevant “extension bulletin” format for “decision-makers” in the public and private sectors
The p​​​​​roject was awarded by the Balaton Group:
and the project amount is USD3,000/=.
Suboptimality game platform and training as a lever for change

The goal of this project is to provide transformative ways for decision-makers: a systemic view where they could experience the benefits of suboptimality to feed robustness in a fluctuating world. We propose to co-create two game platforms where participants could test suboptimal solutions to address their issues: (i) an online platform where users can enter parameters in set conditions (with stochastic variations), with the goal to survive for the longest time (with options ranging from over-optimized to suboptimal inputs), (ii) an in-person training program (small group) where participants share their (real) current issues and attempt to find the most robust way forward, with the help of disruptive/fluctuating elements and pinpointing the added values of their weaker points (once integrated in a systemic view). In both cases, the process forces the users to adapt and transform their projects or initial question until they tick 3 milestones (human health & social health & water-soil-biomass health), followed by a stress test to make sure it is robust. The p​​​​​roject was awarded by the Balaton Group: http://www.balatongroup.org and the project amount is USD20,00/=.
Societal Impacts for Sustainability: Proliferating Thailand’s Sustainability Village Know-How to Scotland and Singapore.

Distill a set of ideas, activities, and lessons from living and learning in the sustainability village in Thailand that can be readily implemented in Scotland and Singapore to drive sustainability awareness and actions in those countries.
Co-design and test the ideas distilled into feasible implementation plans to be implemented in Scotland and Singapore.
Document the progress, experiences, and best practices that can be readily shared with others.
The p​​​​​roject was awarded by the Balaton Group: http://www.balatongroup.org and the project amount is USD13,700/=.
Learning and Teaching with System Archetypes
Produce extensive written materials on how system archetypes can be effectively applied to solve complex sustainability problems.
Some of these written materials will be published in book form. Others will be distributed via the Internet or directed to a journal.
Produce a carefully designed training curriculum, with participant materials and set of slides for use in training programs on how to use systems archetypes to solve complex sustainability problems.
The p​​​​​roject was awarded by the Balaton Group:
and the project amount is USD20,000/=.
Deepening collaborative efforts in improving systems dynamics application for sustainable development policy analysis: taking China’s Ecology Poverty Alleviation Policy as an example
Develop a report on the application of system dynamics on China’s ecological poverty alleviation policy with first-hand data from the field studies.
Deliver a public presentation on the system dynamics modelling to solve complex sustainability challenge with workshop feedback obtained from various stakeholders.
Publish the finding in the Balaton Group bulletin and other applied research outlet
The p​​​​​roject was awarded by the Balaton Group: http://www.balatongroup.org and the project amount is USD3,000/=.
Improving RC4 student's systems thinking capabilities with LEGO® SERIOUS PLAY®
The project objective is to investigate into the effect of applying LEGO(R) Serious Play(R) method in the teaching of system dynamics module on enhancing student's systems thinking capabilities.
The project grant was founded by the Centre for Teaching and Learning of NUS and for an amount of S$9,535.00/=
